item.title: How to steal corporate secrets in 20 minutes: Ask
item.description: LinuxSecurity.com: A few companies in the Fortune 500 need to upgrade their Web browsers. And while they're at it, a little in-house training on social engineering wouldn't be a bad idea, either.

item.title: GSM Phone Hack FAQ: What You Should Know
item.description: LinuxSecurity.com: A researcher at the Def Con security conference in Las Vegas demonstrated that he could impersonate a GSM cell tower and intercept mobile phone calls using only $1500 worth of equipment. The cost-effective solution brings mobile phone snooping to the masses, and raises some concerns for mobile phone security.

item.title: AppArmor set for inclusion in Linux kernel
item.description: LinuxSecurity.com: James Morris, the maintainer of the Linux kernel's security subsystem, has integrated the kernel code for the AppArmor security extension into his development branch, which forms part of Linux-Next. Shortly afterwards, he announced that he also intends to send the code to Linus Torvalds for integration into the Linux 2.6.36 kernel.

item.title: US Secret Service shows business how to fight cyberthreats
item.description: LinuxSecurity.com: Both types of attack have increased in the past year, according to the 2010 Verizon Data Breach Investigations report in partnership with the US Secret Service. This is the first time private and commercial data has been combined in a data breach report, said Matthijs Van der Wel, head of the EMEA forensics team at Verizon Business.

item.title: GSM Hacking Coming To The Masses Script Kiddy Style
item.description: LinuxSecurity.com: Well it looks like what happened to WEP all those years ago is going to happen to GSM now. The methods have been known, the theory is established but the breaking point is when freely available tools are published that makes it possible for anyone to perform the attacks even without really understanding what is going on.

item.title: Important Lessons to Learn from the Black Hat ATM Hack
item.description: LinuxSecurity.com: A security researcher named Barnaby Jack amazed attendees at the Black Hat security conference by hacking ATM machines in a session titled "Jackpotting Automated Teller Machines Redux". There are some important lessons to be learned from the hacks Jack demonstrated, and they apply to more than just ATM machines.
